COVID-19 is a novel coronavirus strain causing global health emergency
RT-PCR is the current standard test for COVID-19 diagnosis but requires sophisticated lab setup
LAMP is a simpler alternative for molecular testing that operates at a constant temperature
Penn-RAMP is a two-stage isothermal amplification method offering higher sensitivity
Home-based testing for COVID-19 using Penn-RAMP and LAMP techniques
Use of minimally trained personnel and minimal instruments for testing
Potential of colorimetric detection for visual confirmation of results
COVID-19 LAMP shows comparable sensitivity to RT-PCR
Penn-RAMP offers 10 to 100-fold better sensitivity than LAMP and RT-PCR
The need for rapid and accurate point-of-care diagnostics for controlling COVID-19 spread
Hypervalent iodine compounds have unique reactivities and are used as a safer alternative to heavy-metal reagents.
Phenylalanine-based hypervalent iodine macrocycles (HIMs) can bind with alkali metals like lithium and sodium.
HIMs and alkali metals form different supramolecular architectures in solution and solid states, with specific binding angles and patterns.
Secondary bonding interactions like iodine-oxygen contribute to the assembly of HIMs.
NMR titration and crystallography were used to study the binding properties of HIMs with metal cations.
There is a stronger association for HIMs with lithium compared to sodium due to differences in metal size and bonding.
Binding energies for metal complexes are calculated, revealing lithium complexes to be more stable.
Supramolecular systems like HIMs can engage in dynamic covalent chemistry and participate in higher-order assemblies.
Operando experiments can provide insights into structural transformations in battery electrodes.
TiO2-based materials, including the bronze polymorph, are used as electrode materials due to their high power performance and safety.
Tools such as structureMining and similarityMapping assist in modeling PDF data to reveal phase transitions.
Non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) is used to decompose data into meaningful components.
Principal component analysis (PCA) helps filter noise in experimental data.
Phase identification enables understanding of phase evolution during Galvanostatic cycling.
Phase transformations in TiO2 involve both bronze and anatase phases and their lithiated versions.
Model-free analyses can characterize phases in complex multicomponent systems like Li-ion batteries.
PCA noise filtering improves visual inspection of complex data.
NMF analyses reveal reversible phase behaviors during battery charging and discharging.
Ti C T electrodes are characterized using advanced DRT analysis to study charge transfer dynamics.
MXenes, particularly Ti C T , have exceptional electrical conductivity and capacitive properties.
The analysis of electrolyte and substrate interaction is crucial for understanding charge storage mechanisms.
High proton mobility in acidic electrolytes, especially H SO , enhances electrochemical performance.
Ni foam as a substrate shows enhanced performance due to its porosity and conductivity.
DRT analysis allows for the segregation of various electrochemical processes in terms of relaxation times.
Higher potentials slow down charge transfer dynamics as observed in DRT spectra.
The study emphasizes the importance of selecting suitable electrolytes and substrates to optimize electrochemical performance of MXene electrodes.

Ternary nitride compounds consist of two metal cations and nitrogen anion.
Diversity in ternary nitride chemistries contributes to unique structures and properties.
Ternary nitrides have a higher propensity for forming in metastable phases.
Defects in ternary nitrides include intrinsic defects, cation disorder, and extrinsic defects.
Synthesis of ternary nitrides involves controlling the nitrogen chemical potential.
Device applications include optoelectronic devices, ultra-wide bandgap electronics, and energy storage systems.
Challenges include controlling oxygen incorporation and improving synthesis techniques.
Integration with binary nitrides offers potential for expanded application spaces.
MXenes are two-dimensional metal carbides and nitrides with impressive applications in energy storage and electromagnetic interference shielding.
Hybrid MXenes with organic-inorganic bonding (amido- and imido-terminated) enhance structural engineerability.
Synthesis of h-MXenes involves displacement of halides from Br- or Cl-terminated MXenes by deprotonated primary organic amines.
h-MXenes exhibit coherent coupling between organic and inorganic components, displaying Fano resonances in vibrational spectra.
Organic functional groups enable h-MXenes to be dispersed in non-polar solvents, improving colloidal stability.
h-MXenes show improved stability against hydrolysis compared to traditional MXenes, attributed to protective organic layers and surface chemistry.
Techniques like X-ray fluorescence, solid-state NMR, and electron microscopy are crucial for characterizing MXene structure and properties.
